Abstract

Federated Learning (FL) has emerged as a pivotal framework for the development of effective global models (global FL) or personalized models (personalized FL) across clients with heterogeneous, non-iid data distribution. A key challenge in FL is client drift, where data heterogeneity impedes the aggregation of scattered knowledge. Recent studies have tackled the client drift issue by identifying significant divergence in the last classifier layer. To mitigate this divergence, strategies such as freezing the classifier weights and aligning the feature extractor accordingly have proven effective. Although the local alignment between classifier and feature extractor has been studied as a crucial factor in FL, we observe that it may lead the model to overemphasize the observed classes within each client. Thus, our objectives are twofold: (1) enhancing local alignment while (2) preserving the representation of unseen class samples. This approach aims to effectively integrate knowledge from individual clients, thereby improving performance for both global and personalized FL. To achieve this, we introduce a novel algorithm named FedDr+, which empowers local model alignment using dot-regression loss. FedDr+ freezes the classifier as a simplex ETF to align the features and improves aggregated global models by employing a feature distillation mechanism to retain information about unseen/missing classes. Consequently, we provide empirical evidence demonstrating that our algorithm surpasses existing methods that use a frozen classifier to boost alignment across the diverse distribution.

1 Introduction

Federated Learning (FL)Â [1, 2, 3] is a privacy-aware distributed learning strategy that employs data from multiple clients while ensuring their data privacy. A foundational method in FL, known as FedAvgÂ [1], involves four iterative phases: (1) distributing a global model to clients, (2) training local models using each clientâ€™s private dataset, (3) transmitting the locally trained models back to the server, and (4) aggregating these models. This method effectively protects privacy without requiring the transmission of raw data to the server. However, a significant challenge in FL is data heterogeneity, called non-iidness, which refers to the different underlying data distribution across clients. Such variance can cause client drift during training, obstructing the convergence of the aggregated model and significantly reducing its effectiveness.

To address client drift in non-iid scenarios, recent worksÂ [2, 4, 5, 6] have identified that the last classifier layer in neural networks is particularly vulnerable to this issue. Hence, they suggest strategies that freeze the classifier while updating only the feature extractor. These approaches aim to enhance the alignment between the frozen classifier and the output from the feature extractor. For instance, FedBABUÂ [2] employs various classifier initialization techniques, keeping it fixed during the training of the feature extractor. The methods proposed inÂ [4, 5, 6, 7, 8] utilize more robust initialization, the Equiangular Tight Frame (ETF) classifierÂ [9], to replace traditional random initialization and improve the local alignment strategy.

A frozen classifier is also extensively explored in other research areas, such as class imbalanceÂ [10] and class incremental learningÂ [11], with a consistent objective similar to aforementioned FL studiesâ€”enhancing alignment. Recently, these fields have advanced by introducing and utilizing a novel type of loss, called dot-regression loss â„’DRsubscriptâ„’DR\mathcal{L}_{\text{DR}}, which aims to achieve alignment rapidly. In summary, â„’DRsubscriptâ„’DR\mathcal{L}_{\text{DR}} originates from the decomposition analysis of cross-entropy (CE) loss, which includes pulling and pushing components. As suggested inÂ [10], the pulling component is a force that attracts features to the target class, whereas the pushing component is a force that drives features away from other non-target classes. â„’DRsubscriptâ„’DR\mathcal{L}_{\text{DR}} discards the pushing component, as it slows down convergence to the desired alignment (refer toÂ FigureÂ 1).

Following the advancement of leveraging the frozen classifier with dot-regression loss, we investigate the application of this loss to FL. However, our findings indicate that dot-regression loss does not necessarily lead to sufficient performance improvement of the aggregated server-side model, although it enhances local alignment as intended. We observe that this drawback stems from the handling of unseen class samples. Specifically, while alignment improves for the classes in the local training dataset, it significantly deteriorates for unseen classes. This observation highlights the need to preserve the representation of unobserved classes during local training. To address this issue, we propose a training mechanism, termed FedDr+, that employs dot-regression loss alongside feature distillation that reduces the distance between feature vectors of local and global models.

Contributions.Â  Our main contributions are summarized as follows:

  • â€¢

    We find that dot-regression loss is not easily compatible with FL, although it can enhance the alignment of seen classes. The drawback comes from a significant loss of information on unseen classes, which is vital in the global model perspective. Therefore, we aim to preserve information of unseen classes within the FL system.

  • â€¢

    To preserve global knowledge, including unseen class information while maintaining the advantages of â„’DRsubscriptâ„’DR\mathcal{L}_{\text{DR}}, we propose FedDr+, which utilizes a feature distillation when training local models. This regularizer prevents the model from focusing solely on the local alignment.

  • â€¢

    We verify that the proposed method surpasses the conventional algorithms in both global and personalized FL under various datasets and non-iid settings.

2.2 Dot-Regression Loss for Faster Feature Alignment

Dot-regression loss â„’DRsubscriptâ„’DR\mathcal{L}_{\text{DR}}.Â  This lossÂ [10] facilitates a faster alignment of feature vectors (penultimate layer outputs) fâ€‹(x;ğœ½)âˆˆâ„dğ‘“ğ‘¥ğœ½superscriptâ„ğ‘‘f(x;\bm{\theta})\in\mathbb{R}^{d} to the true class direction of vysubscriptğ‘£ğ‘¦v_{y}, reducing the cosine angle as follows:

where cosâ¡(vec1,vec2)subscriptvec1subscriptvec2\cos(\mathrm{vec}_{1},\mathrm{vec}_{2}) denotes the cosine of the angle between two vectors âˆ â€‹(vec1,vec2)âˆ subscriptvec1subscriptvec2\angle(\mathrm{vec}_{1},\mathrm{vec}_{2}).

The main motivation is that the gradient of the cross-entropy (CE) loss for the feature vector can be decomposed into a pulling and pushing gradient, and recent work indicates that we can achieve better convergence by removing the pushing effectÂ [10, 12]. The pulling gradient aligns fâ€‹(x;ğœ½)ğ‘“ğ‘¥ğœ½f(x;\bm{\theta}) with vysubscriptğ‘£ğ‘¦v_{y}, while the pushing gradient ensures fâ€‹(x;ğœ½)ğ‘“ğ‘¥ğœ½f(x;\bm{\theta}) does not align with vcsubscriptğ‘£ğ‘v_{c} for all câ‰ yğ‘ğ‘¦c\neq y (AppendixÂ B details the exact form of pulling and pushing gradients). Since â„’DRsubscriptâ„’DR\mathcal{L}_{\text{DR}} directly attracts features to the true-class classifier, it drops the pushing gradient, thereby increasing the convergence speed for maximizing cosâ¡(fâ€‹(x;ğœ½),vy)ğ‘“ğ‘¥ğœ½subscriptğ‘£ğ‘¦\cos(f(x;\bm{\theta}),v_{y}).

Frozen ETF classifier.Â  Since â„’DRsubscriptâ„’DR\mathcal{L}_{\text{DR}} focuses on aligning feature vectors with the true-class classifier, the classifier is not required to be trained. Instead, we construct the classifier to satisfy the simplex Equiangular Tight Frame (ETF) condition, a constructive way to achieve maximum angular separation between class vectorsÂ [10, 11]. Concretely, we initialize the classifier weight ğ‘½ğ‘½\bm{V} as follows and freeze it throughout training:

3 When Dot-Regression Loss Meets Federated Learning

Given our focus on applying â„’DRsubscriptâ„’DR\mathcal{L}_{\text{DR}} to FL, we first examine its impact on FL models compared to the CE loss â„’CEsubscriptâ„’CE\mathcal{L}_{\text{CE}}. In summary, we find that while â„’DRsubscriptâ„’DR\mathcal{L}_{\text{DR}} improves alignment and performance on observed class labels, it faces challenge with unobserved classes222While we use the term â€œunobservedâ€ in this context, it also applies to â€œrarelyâ€ existing classes., which are essential for the generalization objective. To address this issue, we propose FedDr+, which integrates â„’DRsubscriptâ„’DR\mathcal{L}_{\text{DR}} with a novel feature distillation loss. We then evaluate FedDr+ by analyzing the effect of feature distillation and compare it with various FL algorithms and regularizers.

Experimental configuration.Â  In this section, we conduct experiments on CIFAR-100Â [13] with a shard non-iid setting (sğ‘ s=10), where each client contains at most 10 classes. We additionally employ LDA setting (Î±ğ›¼\alpha=0.1) in SectionÂ 3.4. Refer to SectionÂ 4 for more details on the dataset configuration. The model is trained for 320 communication rounds, randomly selecting 10% of clients in each round, and the learning rate is decayed at 160thsuperscript160th160^{\text{th}} and 240thsuperscript240th240^{\text{th}} rounds.

3.1 Impact of Dot-Regression Loss on Local and Global Models

We investigate the performance of local models on average when trained with â„’DRsubscriptâ„’DR\mathcal{L}_{\text{DR}} compared to â„’CEsubscriptâ„’CE\mathcal{L}_{\text{CE}}. InÂ FigureÂ 3â€“3, we calculate the statistics on two datasets: the observed class set ğ’ªisuperscriptğ’ªğ‘–\mathcal{O}^{i}, which includes classes present in each clientâ€™s training data Dtrainisuperscriptsubscriptğ·trainğ‘–D_{\text{train}}^{i}, and the unobserved class set ğ’°isuperscriptğ’°ğ‘–\mathcal{U}^{i}, consisting of classes unseen during training. This partition highlights the challenges associated with generalizing to unseen classes in FL.

First, we evaluate the feature-classifier alignment cosâ¡(fâ€‹(x;ğœ½ri),vy)ğ‘“ğ‘¥superscriptsubscriptğœ½ğ‘Ÿğ‘–subscriptğ‘£ğ‘¦\cos(f(x;\bm{\theta}_{r}^{i}),v_{y}) and accuracy of each local model on the test data (FigureÂ 3). We then observe the amount of change from the given global model to each local model in every communication round (FigureÂ 3). For instance, the alignment gap is denoted by cosâ¡(fâ€‹(x;ğœ½ri),vy)âˆ’cosâ¡(fâ€‹(x;ğœ½râˆ’1g),vy)ğ‘“ğ‘¥superscriptsubscriptğœ½ğ‘Ÿğ‘–subscriptğ‘£ğ‘¦ğ‘“ğ‘¥superscriptsubscriptğœ½ğ‘Ÿ1ğ‘”subscriptğ‘£ğ‘¦\cos(f(x;\bm{\theta}_{r}^{i}),v_{y})-\cos(f(x;\bm{\theta}_{r-1}^{g}),v_{y}).

Performance analysis of local models.Â  FigureÂ 3 shows that â„’DRsubscriptâ„’DR\mathcal{L}_{\text{DR}}, by focusing its pulling effects exclusively on observed classes within a clientâ€™s dataset, effectively enhances alignment and accuracy for these classes. However, this specificity leads to poor generalization on unobserved classes, resulting in significantly weaker performance than models trained with â„’CEsubscriptâ„’CE\mathcal{L}_{\text{CE}}. FigureÂ 3 displays the different impacts on ğ’ªisuperscriptğ’ªğ‘–\mathcal{O}^{i} and ğ’°isuperscriptğ’°ğ‘–\mathcal{U}^{i} during updates from the global model to local models. â„’DRsubscriptâ„’DR\mathcal{L}_{\text{DR}} significantly boosts alignment and accuracy for ğ’ªisuperscriptğ’ªğ‘–\mathcal{O}^{i} but causes significant reductions for ğ’°isuperscriptğ’°ğ‘–\mathcal{U}^{i}.

Global model accuracy result.Â  We confirm that â„’DRsubscriptâ„’DR\mathcal{L}_{\text{DR}} shows superior accuracy for ğ’ªisuperscriptğ’ªğ‘–\mathcal{O}^{i} compared to â„’CEsubscriptâ„’CE\mathcal{L}_{\text{CE}} but is less effective at generalizing to ğ’°isuperscriptğ’°ğ‘–\mathcal{U}^{i}. In the shard setting (s=10ğ‘ 10s=10)â€”where each client has access to at most 10 out of 100 classesâ€”this shortcoming significantly reduces the global modelâ€™s overall accuracy (â„’DRsubscriptâ„’DR\mathcal{L}_{\text{DR}}: 42.52%percent\% vs. â„’CEsubscriptâ„’CE\mathcal{L}_{\text{CE}}: 46.38%percent\%). Thus, it is crucial to develop methods that retain the strengths of â„’DRsubscriptâ„’DR\mathcal{L}_{\text{DR}}, i.e.,Â alignment of observed classes, while improving generalization for unobserved classes, highlighting the need for more adaptive loss functions in FL.

3.2 FedDr+: Dot-Regression and Feature Distillation for Federated Learning

We propose FedDr+ to mitigate forgetting unobserved classes while retaining the strengths of dot-regression loss in aligning features of observed classes. Using â„’DRsubscriptâ„’DR\mathcal{L}_{\text{DR}} with the frozen classifier ğ‘½ğ‘½\bm{V}, FedDr+ includes a regularizer that fully distills the global modelâ€™s feature vectors fâ€‹(x;ğœ½g)âˆˆâ„dğ‘“ğ‘¥superscriptğœ½ğ‘”superscriptâ„ğ‘‘f(x;\bm{\theta}^{g})\in\mathbb{R}^{d} to the client features fâ€‹(x;ğœ½)ğ‘“ğ‘¥ğœ½f(x;\bm{\theta}), to enhance generalization across all classes. The proposed loss function â„’Dr+subscriptâ„’Dr+\mathcal{L}_{\text{Dr+}}, shown in Eq.Â (missing)Â 4, combines â„’DRsubscriptâ„’DR\mathcal{L}_{\text{DR}} with a regularizer â„’FDâ€‹(x;ğœ½,ğœ½g)=1dâ€‹â€–fâ€‹(x;ğœ½)âˆ’fâ€‹(x;ğœ½g)â€–22subscriptâ„’FDğ‘¥ğœ½superscriptğœ½ğ‘”1ğ‘‘superscriptsubscriptnormğ‘“ğ‘¥ğœ½ğ‘“ğ‘¥superscriptğœ½ğ‘”22\mathcal{L}_{\text{FD}}(x;\bm{\theta},\bm{\theta}^{g})=\frac{1}{d}\|f(x;\bm{\theta})-f(x;\bm{\theta}^{g})\|_{2}^{2}. Unless specified, we use a scaling parameter Î²=0.9ğ›½0.9\beta=0.9 throughout the paper.

â„’Dr+â€‹(x,y;ğœ½,ğœ½g,ğ‘½)=Î²â‹…â„’DRâ€‹(x,y;ğœ½,ğ‘½)+(1âˆ’Î²)â‹…â„’FDâ€‹(x;ğœ½,ğœ½g)subscriptâ„’Dr+ğ‘¥ğ‘¦ğœ½superscriptğœ½ğ‘”ğ‘½â‹…ğ›½subscriptâ„’DRğ‘¥ğ‘¦ğœ½ğ‘½â‹…1ğ›½subscriptâ„’FDğ‘¥ğœ½superscriptğœ½ğ‘”\mathcal{L}_{\text{Dr+}}(x,y;\bm{\theta},\bm{\theta}^{g},\bm{V})=\beta\cdot\mathcal{L}_{\text{DR}}(x,y;\bm{\theta},\bm{V})+(1-\beta)\cdot\mathcal{L}_{\text{FD}}(x;\bm{\theta},\bm{\theta}^{g}) (4)

Why feature distillation?Â  To address data heterogeneity in FL, various distillation methods have been explored, including model parametersÂ [2, 14, 15, 16], logit-related measurementÂ [16, 17, 18, 19, 20, 21, 22], and co-distillationÂ [23, 24]. In contrast, we utilize the feature distillationÂ [25] technique because the feature directly concerns alignment. On the other hand, logits lose information from features when projected onto a frozen ETF classifierÂ [25, 26, 27, 28]. By distilling features, we leverage the global, differentiated knowledge for each data input xğ‘¥x. This approach aims to minimize blind drift towards observed classes, and hence, we expect it to enhance overall generalization.

3.3 Effect of Feature Distillation

Our findings from SectionÂ 3.1 indicate that â„’DRsubscriptâ„’DR\mathcal{L}_{\text{DR}} is unsuitable for the heterogeneous FL environment. This is primarily because there is a notable gap in how features align with the fixed classifier between ğ’ªisuperscriptğ’ªğ‘–\mathcal{O}^{i} and ğ’°isuperscriptğ’°ğ‘–\mathcal{U}^{i}. To assess the effect of feature distillation (â„’FDsubscriptâ„’FD\mathcal{L}_{\text{FD}}), which imposes a constraint on the feature distance â€–fâ€‹(x;ğœ½ri)âˆ’fâ€‹(x;ğœ½râˆ’1g)â€–2subscriptnormğ‘“ğ‘¥superscriptsubscriptğœ½ğ‘Ÿğ‘–ğ‘“ğ‘¥superscriptsubscriptğœ½ğ‘Ÿ1ğ‘”2\|f(x;\bm{\theta}_{r}^{i})-f(x;\bm{\theta}_{r-1}^{g})\|_{2} for xâˆˆğ’ªiğ‘¥superscriptğ’ªğ‘–x\in\mathcal{O}^{i}, we measure this distance for both ğ’ªisuperscriptğ’ªğ‘–\mathcal{O}^{i} and ğ’°isuperscriptğ’°ğ‘–\mathcal{U}^{i} from the models trained with â„’DRsubscriptâ„’DR\mathcal{L}_{\text{DR}} and â„’Dr+subscriptâ„’Dr+\mathcal{L}_{\text{Dr+}}. We additionally analyze the angle distance, âˆ â€‹(fâ€‹(x;ğœ½ri),fâ€‹(x;ğœ½râˆ’1g))âˆ ğ‘“ğ‘¥superscriptsubscriptğœ½ğ‘Ÿğ‘–ğ‘“ğ‘¥superscriptsubscriptğœ½ğ‘Ÿ1ğ‘”\angle(f(x;\bm{\theta}_{r}^{i}),f(x;\bm{\theta}_{r-1}^{g})), and feature norm difference, â€–fâ€‹(x;ğœ½ri)â€–2âˆ’â€–fâ€‹(x;ğœ½râˆ’1g)â€–2subscriptnormğ‘“ğ‘¥superscriptsubscriptğœ½ğ‘Ÿğ‘–2subscriptnormğ‘“ğ‘¥superscriptsubscriptğœ½ğ‘Ÿ1ğ‘”2\|f(x;\bm{\theta}_{r}^{i})\|_{2}-\|f(x;\bm{\theta}_{r-1}^{g})\|_{2}, as these factors influence the feature distance. These values are averaged over the selected client set ğ’®rsubscriptğ’®ğ‘Ÿ\mathcal{S}_{r}.

Feature distillation stabilizes the feature dynamics.Â  By adding â„’FDsubscriptâ„’FD\mathcal{L}_{\text{FD}}, as revealed in 4(a), the local model trained with â„’Dr+subscriptâ„’Dr+\mathcal{L}_{\text{Dr+}} shows a reduction in feature distance for observed classes, compared to the model trained with â„’DRsubscriptâ„’DR\mathcal{L}_{\text{DR}}. This reduction happens even for unobserved classes. As demonstrated inÂ 4(b) andÂ 4(c), reduction of feature distance originates from reducing the feature angle distance and feature norm difference for both class sets. In both local models trained with â„’DRsubscriptâ„’DR\mathcal{L}_{\text{DR}} and â„’Dr+subscriptâ„’Dr+\mathcal{L}_{\text{Dr+}}, there is a trend where the angle is significantly larger for ğ’°isuperscriptğ’°ğ‘–\mathcal{U}^{i} than for ğ’ªisuperscriptğ’ªğ‘–\mathcal{O}^{i}Â (4(b)), while the norm difference is smaller for ğ’°isuperscriptğ’°ğ‘–\mathcal{U}^{i} than for ğ’ªisuperscriptğ’ªğ‘–\mathcal{O}^{i}Â (4(c)). This large angle distance of ğ’°isuperscriptğ’°ğ‘–\mathcal{U}^{i} leads to the degradation of the feature-classifier alignment. By minimizing the angle distance via feature distillation, the global modelâ€™s accuracy improved substantially, rising from 42.52%percent42.5242.52\% with â„’DRsubscriptâ„’DR\mathcal{L}_{\text{DR}} to 48.69%percent48.6948.69\%with â„’Dr+subscriptâ„’Dr+\mathcal{L}_{\text{Dr+}}.

Stabilized features enhance alignment and accuracy.

We confirm that feature distillation term â„’FDsubscriptâ„’FD\mathcal{L}_{\text{FD}} stabilizes feature dynamics for both ğ’ªisuperscriptğ’ªğ‘–\mathcal{O}^{i} and ğ’°isuperscriptğ’°ğ‘–\mathcal{U}^{i}, enhancing the global modelâ€™s capabilities. While the feature difference is stabilized via â„’FDsubscriptâ„’FD\mathcal{L}_{\text{FD}}, it is essential to verify whether this leads to improved alignment and accuracy.

InÂ FigureÂ 5, we examine in both aspects and illustrate the training curve. Our proposed algorithm, i.e.,Â â„’Dr+subscriptâ„’Dr+\mathcal{L}_{\text{Dr+}}, demonstrates superior performance for both ğ’ªisuperscriptğ’ªğ‘–\mathcal{O}^{i} and ğ’°isuperscriptğ’°ğ‘–\mathcal{U}^{i} in terms of alignment and accuracy. Notably, even with the addition of a term to the dot-regression loss, alignment is improved. We attribute this improvement to the enhanced knowledge of the global model which is preserved by preventing the forgetting of previously trained knowledge. Even though the proposed regularizer demonstrates a reasonable regularizing effect, one question remains: â€œIs it superior to other previously used regularizers?â€

3.4 Synergistic Effect with Different Types of FL Algorithms and Regularizers

We answer the above question by evaluating the synergy effect of various FL algorithms by maintaining their original training loss and incorporating specific regularizers, as suggested in Eq.Â (missing)Â 4. Our study includes FedAvgÂ [1] without classifier freezing and other advanced frameworks such as FedBABUÂ [2], SphereFedÂ [4], FedETFÂ [5], and dot-regression, all of which update local models while freezing the classifier. In addition to the FD regularizer, we consider regularizers such as ProxÂ [14] to constrain the distance between local and global model parameters, and several logit-based regularizersâ€”KDÂ [29], NTDÂ [17, 31], and LDÂ [30]â€”to keep logit-related measurement of local models from deviating significantly from that of the global model. Specifically, KD applies the softened softmax probability from the logit vector, NTD does the same but excludes the true class dimension, and LD distills the entire logit vector.

TableÂ 1 demonstrates that FedDr+ â€‰(dot-regressionâ€‰+â€‰FD) achieves the best performance. Generally, Prox tends to be less effective than logit-based regularizers, which are often outperformed by FD across most algorithms. This is because, as noted inÂ SectionÂ 3.2, with the frozen classifier, features are expected to have rich information to mitigate the drift. Prox uniformly regularizes all data instances, whereas logit and feature regularizers adapt to both model parameters and data instances, offering more refined control. Specifically, FD regularizer, with its higher dimensionality, captures the global modelâ€™s information more precisely than logit-based ones, resulting in better synergy.

4 Experiments and Results

In this section, we present the experimental results of FedDr+, encompassing both global federated learning (GFL) and personalized federated learning (PFL). Additionally, we perform various hyper-parameter sensitivity analyses, exploring the impact of varying local epochs and the client sampling ratio on performance, as well as the effect of different Î²ğ›½\beta values in FedDr+.

4.1 Experimental Setup

Dataset and models.Â  To simulate a realistic FL scenario involving 100 clients, we conduct extensive studies on two widely used datasets: CIFAR-10 and CIFAR-100Â [13]. For CIFAR-10, we employ VGG11Â [32], while for CIFAR-100, MobileNetÂ [33] is used. The training data is distributed among 100 clients using sharding and the LDA (Latent Dirichlet Allocation) partition strategies.

Following the convention, sharding distributes the data into non-overlapping shards of equal size, each shard encompassing |Dtrain|100Ã—ssubscriptğ·train100ğ‘ \frac{|D_{\text{train}}|}{100\times s} and |Dtest|100Ã—ssubscriptğ·test100ğ‘ \frac{|D_{\text{test}}|}{100\times s} samples per class, where sğ‘ s denotes the number of shards per client. On the other hand, LDA involves sampling a probability vector from Dirichlet distribution, pc=(pc,1,pc,2,â‹¯,pc,100)âˆ¼Dirâ€‹(Î±)subscriptğ‘ğ‘subscriptğ‘ğ‘1subscriptğ‘ğ‘2â‹¯subscriptğ‘ğ‘100similar-toDirğ›¼p_{c}=(p_{c,1},p_{c,2},\cdots,p_{c,100})\sim\text{Dir}(\alpha), and allocating a proportion pc,ksubscriptğ‘ğ‘ğ‘˜p_{c,k} of instances of class câˆˆ[C]ğ‘delimited-[]ğ¶c\in[C] to each client kâˆˆ[100]ğ‘˜delimited-[]100k\in[100]. Smaller values of sğ‘ s and Î±ğ›¼\alpha increase the level of data heterogeneity.

Implementation details.Â  In each round of communication, a fraction of clients equal to 0.1 is randomly selected to participate in the training process. The total number of communication rounds is 320. The initial learning rate and the number of local epochs for CIFAR-10 and CIFAR-100 are determined through grid searches, with the detailed process and results provided in AppendixÂ C. The learning rate Î·ğœ‚\eta is decayed by a factor of 0.1 at the 160th and 240th communication rounds. The number of local epochs is set to 10 for CIFAR-10 and 3 for CIFAR-100 in the main experiments.333TableÂ 2 is constructed using the code structure from https://github.com/Lee-Gihun/FedNTD, while the rest of the implementation is based on https://github.com/jhoon-oh/FedBABU.

4.2 Global Federated Learning Results

We compare FedDr+ with a range of GFL algorithms, considering both non-freezing and freezing classifier approaches. Among non-freezing classifiers, FedDr+ competes with FedAvgÂ [1], SCAFFOLDÂ [34], FedNTDÂ [17], and FedExPÂ [35]. FedDr+ is also evaluated against freezing classifier algorithms such as FedBABUÂ [2], SphereFedÂ [4], and FedETFÂ [5]. Among the baseline algorithms, SCAFFOLD incurs a communication cost three times higher per round, denoted as (Ã—3absent3\times 3). Our experiments encompass heterogeneous settings involving sharding and LDA non-IID environments.

TableÂ 2 summarizes the accuracy comparison between the state-of-the-art GFL methods and FedAvg under various conditions. While specific methods demonstrated effectiveness in particular scenarios, some of these frequently underperformed relative to the robustness of FedAvg. For example, SCAFFOLD shown strong performance in the less heterogeneous sharding setting on CIFAR-10; however, it failed in model training under the highly heterogeneous LDA condition with Î±=0.1ğ›¼0.1\alpha=0.1. Notably, FedDr+ consistently exceeded all baseline methods in performance across diverse experimental conditions and often achieved state-of-the-art results. FedDr+ demonstrated exceptional performance in highly heterogeneous FL environments, particularly excelling in the CIFAR-100 LDA configuration with Î±=0.05ğ›¼0.05\alpha=0.05, achieving a notable 3.15% improvement over all baseline models.

4.3 Personalized Federated Learning Results

We introduce FedDr+â€‰FT, inspired by prior workÂ [2, 4, 5, 40], which enhances personalization by leveraging local data to fine-tune the global federated learning (GFL) model. We fine-tune the FedDr+ GFL model using â„’Dr+subscriptâ„’Dr+\mathcal{L}_{\text{Dr+}} to create FedDr+â€‰FT, i.e.,Â 2-step approach. For a comprehensive analysis, we compare FedDr+â€‰FT with existing personalized federated learning (PFL) methods, including 1-step approaches, i.e.,Â creating PFL models from scratch, such as FedPerÂ [36], Per-FedAvgÂ [37], FedRepÂ [38], and DittoÂ [39], as well as 2-step methods such as FedAVG-FT, FedBABU-FTÂ [2], SphereFed-FTÂ [4], and FedETF-FTÂ [5]. Additionally, we compare these methods with various simple local models that have not undergone federated learning: (1) Local only (â„’CEsubscriptâ„’CE\mathcal{L}_{\text{CE}}), trained with â„’CEsubscriptâ„’CE\mathcal{L}_{\text{CE}}, (2) Local only (â„’CEsubscriptâ„’CE\mathcal{L}_{\text{CE}}â€‰+â€‰ETF), trained with â„’CEsubscriptâ„’CE\mathcal{L}_{\text{CE}} and initializing the classifier with an ETF classifier, and (3) Local only (â„’DRsubscriptâ„’DR\mathcal{L}_{\text{DR}}), trained using â„’DRsubscriptâ„’DR\mathcal{L}_{\text{DR}}.

In TableÂ 3, we first compare the performance of simple local models in PFL by examining â„’DRsubscriptâ„’DR\mathcal{L}_{\text{DR}} and â„’CEsubscriptâ„’CE\mathcal{L}_{\text{CE}}. With a large number of classes (Cğ¶C=100), the ETF classifier, which is also nearly classwise orthogonal, performs similarly to random initialization. When comparing FedDr+â€‰FT with other 2-step methods, FedDr+â€‰FT consistently demonstrates superior performance. This aligns with previous researchÂ [45, 46] suggesting that fine-tuning from a well-initialized model yields better PFL performance. Additionally, compared with 1-step algorithms, FedDr+â€‰FT continues to show superiority, outperforming all baseline methods across all settings.

4.4 Sensitivity Analysis

We explore the impact of varying client sampling ratio and local epochs on performance, as well as the effect of different Î²ğ›½\beta values in FedDr+, as detailed in FigureÂ 6. All experiments are conducted on MobileNet using the CIFAR-100 dataset with sharding (sğ‘ s=10) and LDA (Î±ğ›¼\alpha=0.1).

Effect of client sampling ratio and local epochs.Â  We evaluate the sensitivity of hyperparameters in FedDr+ by comparing it to baselines under varying client sampling ratio and local epochs, starting from the default setting of client sampling ratio of 0.1 and local epoch of 3. Compared to FedAvg (without classifier freezing), FedBABU and SphereFed (all with classifier freezing) show performance improvements with increasing fraction ratios, but FedDr+ consistently outperforms the baselines. The number of local epochs is crucial in FL; too few epochs result in underfitting, while too many cause client drift, degrading global model performance. The default setting of local epochs 3 is optimal for all baselines, with FedDr+ achieving the best performance. Although performance generally declines when deviating from this peak point, FedDr+ remains the best or highly competitive.

Weight ratio Î²ğ›½\beta analysis.Â  We analyze the effect of scaling parameter in FedDr+ by varying Î²ğ›½\beta while keeping other hyperparameters constant. The performance is evaluated for Î²âˆˆ{0,0.1,0.3,0.5,0.7,0.9,1.0}ğ›½00.10.30.50.70.91.0\beta\in\{0,0.1,0.3,0.5,0.7,0.9,1.0\}. 5 Related Work

Federated learning.Â  Federated Learning (FL) is a decentralized approach to deep learning where multiple clients collaboratively train a global model using their own datasetsÂ [1, 2, 14, 47]. This approach faces challenges due to data heterogeneity across clients, causing instability in the learning processÂ [34, 48]. To address this problem, strategies like classifier variance reduction in FedPVRÂ [49] and virtual features in CCVRÂ [48] have been proposed. Additionally, it is essential to distinguish between Global Federated Learning (GFL) and Personalized Federated Learning (PFL), as these are crucial concepts in FL. GFL aims to improve a single global modelâ€™s performance across clients by addressing data heterogeneity through methods like client drift mitigationÂ [14, 34, 35], enhanced aggregation schemesÂ [50, 51], and data sharing techniques using public or synthesized datasetsÂ [20, 48, 52]. Otherwise, PFL focuses on creating personalized models for individual clients by decoupling feature extractors and classifiers for unique updatesÂ [2, 36, 38], modifying local loss functionsÂ [37, 39], and using prototype communication techniquesÂ [53, 54].

Frozen classifier in FL.Â  By focusing on alignment, previous studies have attempted to mitigate data heterogeneity by freezing the classifier [2, 4, 5]. Nevertheless, these methods have yet to effectively improve the alignment between features and their corresponding classifier weights. Motivated by this, we integrated the dot-regression method into federated learning to achieve a better-aligned local model by freezing the classifier. Dot-regression, proposed to address class imbalance, focuses on aligning feature vectors to a fixed classifier, demonstrating superior alignment performance compared to previous approaches. However, optimizing the dot-regression loss to align feature vectors with a fixed classifier caused the local model to lose information on unobserved classes, thereby degrading global model performance. To address these issues, FedLoGeÂ [8] employing realignment techniques to ensure the well-aligned local modelâ€™s performance translated to the global model. Additionally, in FedGELAÂ [6], the classifier is globally fixed as a simplex ETF while being locally adapted to personal distributions. Also, FedPACÂ [54] addressed these challenges by leveraging global semantic knowledge for explicit local-global feature alignment. Besides alignment-focused methods, there have been various attempts to maintain good local model performance in the global modelÂ [55, 56, 57].

Knowledge distillation in FL.Â  Multiple studies have explored knowledge transfer techniques Â [18, 19, 58, 59, 60]. Specifically, knowledge distillation (KD) has been widely studied in FL settings, such as in FedMDÂ [16] and FedDFÂ [20], where a pretrained teacher model transfers knowledge to a student model. Additional distillation-based methods, such as FedFedÂ [61] and co-distillation framework for PFLÂ [23, 24], have also been explored. In contrast to existing methods, we propose a loss function incorporating feature distillation to maintain the performance of both local and global models. To our knowledge, this is the first application of feature distillation in FL. This approach highlights the importance of distinguishing between GFL and PFL.

6 Conclusion

Motivated by the recent FL methods enhancing feature alignment with a fixed classifier, we first investigate the effects of applying dot-regression loss for FL. Since the dot-regression is the most direct method for feature-classifier alignment, we find it improves alignment and accuracy in local models but degrades the performance of the global model. This happens because local clients trained with dot-regression tend to forget classes that have not been observed. To address this, we propose FedDr+, combining dot-regression with a feature distillation method. By regularizing the deviation of local features from global features, FedDr+ allows local models to maintain knowledge about all classes during training, thereby ultimately preserving general knowledge of the global model. Our method achieves top performance in global and personalized FL experiments, even when data is distributed unevenly across devices (non-IID settings).

Appendix A Notations

Appendix B Preliminaries: Pulling and Pushing Feature Gradients in CE

In this section, we first calculate the classifier gradient for features and introduce the pulling and pushing effects of the cross-entropy objective.

B.1 Feature Gradient of â„’CEsubscriptâ„’CE\mathcal{L}_{\text{CE}}

We first provide two lemmas supporting PropositionÂ 1, explaining the behavior of pulling and pushing feature gradients in the cross-entropy (CE) loss.

Lemma 1.

Appendix C Experimental Setup

C.1 Code Implementation

Our implementations are conducted using the PyTorch framework. Specifically, the experiments presented in TableÂ 2 are executed on a single NVIDIA RTX 3090 GPU, based on the code structure from the following repository: https://github.com/Lee-Gihun/FedNTD. The other parts of our study are carried out on a single NVIDIA A5000 GPU, utilizing the code framework from https://github.com/jhoon-oh/FedBABU.

C.2 Datasets, Model, and Optimizer

To simulate a realistic FL scenario, we conduct extensive studies on two widely used datasets: CIFAR-10 and CIFAR-100Â [13]. A momentum optimizer is utilized for all experiments. Unless otherwise noted, the basic setting of our experiments follows the dataset statistics, FL scenario specifications, and optimizer hyperparameters summarized in TableÂ 5.

Note: In terms of dataset information, Cğ¶C represents the number of classes in the dataset, with |Dtrain|subscriptğ·train|D_{\text{train}}| and |Dtest|subscriptğ·test|D_{\text{test}}| indicating the total numbers of training and test data used, respectively. For the federated learning (FL) system specifics, Rğ‘…R indicates the total number of FL rounds, rğ‘Ÿr is the ratio of clients selected for each round, and Eğ¸E denotes the number of local epochs. Local model training utilizes a momentum optimizer where BğµB is the batch size, and mğ‘šm and Î»ğœ†\lambda represent the momentum and weight decay parameters, respectively. The initial learning rate Î·ğœ‚\eta is decayed by a factor of 0.1 at the 160th and 240th communication rounds. The initial learning rate Î·ğœ‚\eta and batch size BğµB were determined via extensive grid search for each algorithm, details outlined in AppendixÂ C.4.

C.3 Non-IID Partition Strategies

To induce heterogeneity in each clientâ€™s training and test data (Dtraini,Dtestisuperscriptsubscriptğ·trainğ‘–superscriptsubscriptğ·testğ‘–D_{\text{train}}^{i},D_{\text{test}}^{i}), we distribute the entire class-balanced datasets, Dtrainsubscriptğ·trainD_{\text{train}} and Dtestsubscriptğ·testD_{\text{test}}, among 100 clients using both sharding and Latent Dirichlet Allocation (LDA) partitioning strategies:

  • â€¢

    ShardingÂ [1, 2]: We organize the Dtrainsubscriptğ·trainD_{\text{train}} and Dtestsubscriptğ·testD_{\text{test}} by label and divide them into non-overlapping shards of equal size. Each shard encompasses |Dtrain|100Ã—ssubscriptğ·train100ğ‘ \frac{|D_{\text{train}}|}{100\times s} and |Dtest|100Ã—ssubscriptğ·test100ğ‘ \frac{|D_{\text{test}}|}{100\times s} samples of the same class, where sğ‘ s denotes the number of shards per client. This sharding technique is used to create Dtrainisuperscriptsubscriptğ·trainğ‘–D_{\text{train}}^{i} and Dtestisuperscriptsubscriptğ·testğ‘–D_{\text{test}}^{i}, which are then distributed to each client iğ‘–i, ensuring that each client has the same number of training and test samples. The data for each client is disjoint. As a result, each client has access to a maximum of sğ‘ s different classes. Decreasing the number of shards per user sğ‘ s increases the level of data heterogeneity among clients.

  • â€¢

    Latent Dirichlet Allocation (LDA)Â [48, 50]: We utilize the LDA technique to create Dtrainisuperscriptsubscriptğ·trainğ‘–D_{\text{train}}^{i} from Dtrainsubscriptğ·trainD_{\text{train}}. This involves sampling a probability vector pc=(pc,1,pc,2,â‹¯,pc,100)âˆ¼Dirâ€‹(Î±)subscriptğ‘ğ‘subscriptğ‘ğ‘1subscriptğ‘ğ‘2â‹¯subscriptğ‘ğ‘100similar-toDirğ›¼p_{c}=(p_{c,1},p_{c,2},\cdots,p_{c,100})\sim\text{Dir}(\alpha) and allocating a proportion pc,ksubscriptğ‘ğ‘ğ‘˜p_{c,k} of instances of class câˆˆ[C]ğ‘delimited-[]ğ¶c\in[C] to each client kâˆˆ[100]ğ‘˜delimited-[]100k\in[100]. Here, Dâ€‹iâ€‹râ€‹(Î±)ğ·ğ‘–ğ‘Ÿğ›¼Dir(\alpha) represents the Dirichlet distribution with the concentration parameter Î±ğ›¼\alpha. The parameter Î±ğ›¼\alpha controls the strength of data heterogeneity, with smaller values leading to stronger heterogeneity among clients. For Dtestisuperscriptsubscriptğ·testğ‘–D_{\text{test}}^{i}, we randomly sample from Dtestsubscriptğ·testD_{\text{test}} to match the class frequency of Dtrainisuperscriptsubscriptğ·trainğ‘–D_{\text{train}}^{i} and distribute it to each client iğ‘–i.

C.4 Hyperparameter Search for Î·ğœ‚\eta and Eğ¸E

To optimize the initial learning rate (Î·ğœ‚\eta) and the number of local epochs (Eğ¸E) for our algorithm, we conduct a grid search on the CIFAR-10 and CIFAR-100 datasets. The process and reasoning are outlined below.

C.4.1 Rationale for Varying Initial Learning Rate (Î·ğœ‚\eta)

The algorithms used in our experiments differ in handling feature normalization within the loss function. Some algorithms apply feature normalization, while others do not. When features fâ€‹(x;ğœ½)ğ‘“ğ‘¥ğœ½f(x;\bm{\theta}) are normalized, the resulting gradient is scaled by 1â€–fâ€‹(x;ğœ½)â€–21subscriptnormğ‘“ğ‘¥ğœ½2\frac{1}{\|f(x;\bm{\theta})\|_{2}}. This scaling effect necessitates a grid search across various learning rates to account for the differences in learning behavior.

C.4.2 Rationale for Varying Local Epochs Eğ¸E

In FL, choosing the appropriate number of local epochs is crucial. Too few epochs can lead to underfitting, while too many can cause client drift. Therefore, finding the optimal number of local epochs is essential by exploring a range of values.

C.4.3 Grid Search Process and Results

Considering the above reasons, we perform grid search for Î·ğœ‚\eta and Eğ¸E on CIFAR-10 and CIFAR-100 datasets. The grid search for CIFAR-10 uses a shard size of 2, while for CIFAR-100, a shard size of 10 is used. The detailed procedures for each dataset are provided below. These optimal settings have also been confirmed to yield good performance in less heterogeneous settings.

CIFAR-10.Â  We examine Î·ğœ‚\eta values from {0.01, 0.05, 0.1, 0.15, 0.2, 0.25, 0.3, 0.35, 0.4, 0.45, 0.5, 0.55, 0.6}. For Eğ¸E, we consider {1, 3, 5, 10, 15}. The optimal learning rates vary by algorithm, and the results are summarized in TableÂ 6. TableÂ 6 also includes the additional hyperparameters used for each algorithm. The notation for these additional hyperparameters follows the conventions used throughout this paper. The optimal number of local epochs is found to be 10 for every algorithm.

CIFAR-100.Â  We examine Î·ğœ‚\eta values from {0.1, 0.3, 0.5, 1.0, 1.5, 2.0, 2.5, 3.0, 3.5, 4.0, 4.5, 5.0, 5.5, 6.0, 6.5, 7.0}. A default initial learning rate of 0.1 is used unless specified otherwise. The optimal learning rates differ by algorithm, and the results are listed in TableÂ 7. TableÂ 7 also includes the additional hyperparameters used for each algorithm. The notation for these additional hyperparameters follows the conventions used throughout this paper. The optimal number of local epochs is found to be 3 for every algorithm.

Appendix D Additional Experiment Results

D.1 Personalized Federated Learning Results

We introduce FedDr+ â€‰FT and dot-regressionâ€‰FT, inspired by prior workÂ [2, 4, 5, 40]. These methods enhance personalization by leveraging local data to fine-tune the GFL model. We investigate the impact of fine-tuning using â„’Dr+subscriptâ„’Dr+\mathcal{L}_{\text{Dr+}} and â„’DRsubscriptâ„’DR\mathcal{L}_{\text{DR}} loss for each GFL model to assess their effectiveness on personalized accuracy. Performance metrics without standard deviations indicate results on Dtestsubscriptğ·testD_{\text{test}}, obtained from the GFL model after the initial step in the 2-step method. Our experiments involve heterogeneous settings with sharding and LDA non-IID environments, using MobileNet on CIFAR-100 datasets. We set sğ‘ s as 10, 20, and 100, and the LDA concentration parameter (Î±ğ›¼\alpha) as 0.05, 0.1, and 0.3. TableÂ 8 provides detailed personalized accuracy results.

Our 2-step process involves first developing the GFL model either using dot-regression or FedDr+. In the second step, we fine-tune this model to create the PFL model, again using â„’DRsubscriptâ„’DR\mathcal{L}_{\text{DR}} or â„’Dr+subscriptâ„’Dr+\mathcal{L}_{\text{Dr+}}. This results in four combinations: Dot-Regressionâ€‰FTâ€‰(â„’DRsubscriptâ„’DR\mathcal{L}_{\text{DR}}), Dot-Regressionâ€‰FTâ€‰(â„’Dr+subscriptâ„’Dr+\mathcal{L}_{\text{Dr+}}), FedDr+ â€‰FTâ€‰(â„’DRsubscriptâ„’DR\mathcal{L}_{\text{DR}}), and FedDr+ â€‰FTâ€‰(â„’Dr+subscriptâ„’Dr+\mathcal{L}_{\text{Dr+}}). When the GFL model is fixed, using â„’DRsubscriptâ„’DR\mathcal{L}_{\text{DR}} for fine-tuning consistently outperforms â„’Dr+subscriptâ„’Dr+\mathcal{L}_{\text{Dr+}} across all settings, because dot-regression focuses on local alignment which advantages personalized fine-tuning. Conversely, when the fine-tuning method is fixed, employing â„’Dr+subscriptâ„’Dr+\mathcal{L}_{\text{Dr+}} for the GFL model consistently outperforms â„’DRsubscriptâ„’DR\mathcal{L}_{\text{DR}} across all settings. This aligns with previous researchÂ [45, 46] suggesting that fine-tuning from a well-initialized model yields better PFL performance.

D.2 Elapsed Time Results

We compare FedDr+ with various GFL algorithms for the elapsed time per communication round on CIFAR-100 (sğ‘ s=10). The results, detailed in TableÂ 9, show that FedDr+ exhibits a similar but slightly longer elapsed time than the other algorithms.
